message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Adaptive Dynamic Programming for Control: A Survey and Recent Advances
Paper Abstract: This article reviews the recent development of adaptive dynamic programming (ADP) with applications in control. First, its applications in optimal regulation are introduced, and some skilled and efficient algorithms are presented. Next, the use of ADP to solve game problems, mainly nonzero-sum game problems, is elaborated. It is followed by applications in large-scale systems. Note that although the functions presented in this article are based on continuous-time systems, various applications of ADP in discrete-time systems are also analyzed. Moreover, in each section, not only some existing techniques are discussed, but also possible directions for future work are pointed out. Finally, some overall prospects for the future are given, followed by conclusions of this article. Through a comprehensive and complete investigation of its applications in many existing fields, this article fully demonstrates that the ADP intelligent control method is promising in today's artificial intelligence era. Furthermore, it also plays a significant role in promoting economic and social development.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters
Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of reinforcement learning:

## What is Reinforcement Learning?

Reinforcement learning (RL) is concerned with how an intelligent agent should take actions in a dynamic environment in order to maximize a reward signal.(no content)Reinforcement learning is one of the three basic machine learning paradigms, alongside supervised learning and unsupervised learning.

## How It Works

While supervised learning and unsupervised learning algorithms respectively attempt to discover patterns in labeled and unlabeled data, reinforcement learning involves training an agent through interactions with its environment.(no content)To learn to maximize rewards from these interactions, the agent makes decisions between trying new actions to learn more about the environment (exploration), or using current knowledge of the environment to take the best action (exploitation).

## Key Concepts

The environment is typically stated in the form of a Markov decision process, as many reinforcement learning algorithms use dynamic programming techniques.(no content)Two elements make reinforcement learning powerful: the use of samples to optimize performance, and the use of function approximation to deal with large environments.

## Applications

It has been applied successfully to various problems, including energy storage, robot control, photovoltaic generators, backgammon, checkers, Go (AlphaGo), and autonomous driving systems.(no content)Deep reinforcement learning has been used for a diverse set of applications including but not limited to robotics, video games, natural language processing, computer vision, education, transportation, finance and healthcare.

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about Artificial Intelligence:

## Definition and Core Capabilities

Artificial intelligence (AI) is the capability of computational systems to perform tasks typically associated with human intelligence, such as learning, reasoning, problem-solving, perception, and decision-making.

## Key Areas of Focus

The traditional goals of AI research include learning, reasoning, knowledge representation, planning, natural language processing, perception, and support for robotics.(no content)To reach these goals, AI researchers have adapted and integrated a wide range of techniques, including search and mathematical optimization, formal logic, artificial neural networks, and methods based on statistics, operations research, and economics.

## Historical Development

Artificial intelligence was founded as an academic discipline in 1956, and the field went through multiple cycles of optimism throughout its history, followed by periods of disappointment and loss of funding, known as AI winters.

## Artificial General Intelligence (AGI)

Some companies, such as OpenAI, Google DeepMind and Meta, aim to create artificial general intelligence (AGI) – AI that can complete virtually any cognitive task at least as well as a human.

## Modern Applications and Subfields

Generative artificial intelligence (Generative AI, or GenAI) is a subfield of artificial intelligence that uses generative models to generate text, images, videos, audio, software code or other forms of data. AI is being used across numerous industries including astronomy, architecture, healthcare, media analysis, and military operations.

Based on the search results, here's information about **Dynamic Programming**:

## Overview

Dynamic programming is both a mathematical optimization method and an algorithmic paradigm.(no content)The method was developed by Richard Bellman in the 1950s and has found applications in numerous fields, such as aerospace engineering and economics.

## Core Concept

In both contexts it refers to simplifying a complicated problem by breaking it down into simpler sub-problems in a recursive manner.(no content)In terms of mathematical optimization, dynamic programming usually refers to simplifying a decision by breaking it down into a sequence of decision steps over time.

## Key Requirements

There are two key attributes that a problem must have in order for dynamic programming to be applicable: optimal substructure and overlapping sub-problems.(no content)Optimal substructure means that the solution to a given optimization problem can be obtained by the combination of optimal solutions to its sub-problems.

## Practical Advantage

Dynamic programming takes account of this fact and solves each sub-problem only once. This is achieved through memoizing or storing the solutions to the sub-problems in a table (often an array or hashtable in practice).

## Applications

Dynamic programming is widely used in bioinformatics for tasks such as sequence alignment, protein folding, RNA structure prediction and protein-DNA binding.

Dynamic programming is both a mathematical optimization method and an algorithmic paradigm.(no content)The method was developed by Richard Bellman in the 1950s and has found applications in numerous fields, such as aerospace engineering and economics.

## Core Concept

In both contexts it refers to simplifying a complicated problem by breaking it down into simpler sub-problems in a recursive manner.(no content)In terms of mathematical optimization, dynamic programming usually refers to simplifying a decision by breaking it down into a sequence of decision steps over time.

## Key Requirements

There are two key attributes that a problem must have in order for dynamic programming to be applicable: optimal substructure and overlapping sub-problems.(no content)Optimal substructure means that the solution to a given optimization problem can be obtained by the combination of optimal solutions to its sub-problems.

## Practical Advantage

Dynamic programming takes account of this fact and solves each sub-problem only once. This is achieved through memoizing or storing the solutions to the sub-problems in a table (often an array or hashtable in practice).

## Applications

Dynamic programming is widely used in bioinformatics for tasks such as sequence alignment, protein folding, RNA structure prediction and protein-DNA binding.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about large-scale systems:

## Definition and Context

An ultra-large-scale system (ULSS) is a term used in fields including Computer Science, Software Engineering and Systems Engineering to refer to software intensive systems with unprecedented amounts of hardware, lines of source code, numbers of users, and volumes of data.

## Key Characteristics

ULS systems will necessarily be decentralized in a variety of ways, developed and used by a wide variety of stakeholders with conflicting needs, evolving continuously, and constructed from heterogeneous parts. People will not just be users of a ULS system; they will be elements of the system. The realities of software and hardware failures will be fundamentally integrated into the design and operation of ULS systems.

## Evolution and Recognition

The term ultra-large-scale system was introduced in a 2006 report from the Software Engineering Institute at Carnegie Mellon University authored by Linda Northrop and colleagues.(no content)The term "ultra-large-scale system" (ULSS) is sometimes used interchangeably with the term "large-scale complex IT system" (LSCITS). These two terms were introduced at similar times to describe similar problems, the former being coined in the United States and the latter in the United Kingdom.

## Engineering Challenges

When systems become ultra-large-scale, traditional approaches to engineering and management will no longer be adequate.

Links: [{"title":"Zero-sum game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero-sum_game"},{"title":"Non-cooperative game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-cooperative_game_theory"},{"title":"Game without a value - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_without_a_value"},{"title":"Nonzero: The Logic of Human Destiny - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonzero:_The_Logic_of_Human_Destiny"},{"title":"Mean payoff game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mean_payoff_game"},{"title":"Zero-sum thinking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero-sum_thinking"},{"title":"Quantum refereed game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_refereed_game"},{"title":"Game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_theory"},{"title":"Nim - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nim"},{"title":"Subtraction game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subtraction_game"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about nonzero-sum games:

## Definition

A nonzero-sum game is a situation in which the interacting parties' aggregate gains and losses can be less than or more than zero. In contrast to zero-sum games, in non-zero-sum games, a gain by one player does not necessarily correspond with a loss by another.

## Key Characteristics

Non-zero-sum games can be either competitive or non-competitive.(no content)In a non-zero-sum situation, one decision maker's gain (or loss) does not necessarily result in the other decision makers' loss (or gain). For example, a country with an excess of bananas trading with another country for their excess of apples, where both benefit from the transaction, is in a non-zero-sum situation.

## Examples

Prisoner's Dilemma is a classic non-zero-sum game.(no content)Many games studied by game theorists (including the famed prisoner's dilemma) are non-zero-sum games, because the outcome has net results greater or less than zero.

## Historical Development

Game theory initially addressed two-person zero-sum games, but in the 1950s, it was extended to the study of non zero-sum games, and was eventually applied to a wide range of behavioral relations.

Links: [{"title":"Optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_control"},{"title":"Pseudospectral optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pseudospectral_optimal_control"},{"title":"Control (optimal control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_(optimal_control_theory)"},{"title":"Unscented optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unscented_optimal_control"},{"title":"Stochastic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_control"},{"title":"Machine learning control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning_control"},{"title":"Coherent control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coherent_control"},{"title":"H-infinity methods in control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H-infinity_methods_in_control_theory"},{"title":"PROPT - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PROPT"},{"title":"Witsenhausen's counterexample - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Witsenhausen's_counterexample"}]

Here are the search results for "Optimal control":

## Overview

Optimal control theory is a branch of control theory that deals with finding a control for a dynamical system over a period of time such that an objective function is optimized.(no content)It has numerous applications in science, engineering and operations research.

## Practical Examples

For example, the dynamical system might be a spacecraft with controls corresponding to rocket thrusters, and the objective might be to reach the Moon with minimum fuel expenditure.(no content)Or the dynamical system could be a nation's economy, with the objective to minimize unemployment; the controls in this case could be fiscal and monetary policy.

## Historical Development

The method is largely due to the work of Lev Pontryagin and Richard Bellman in the 1950s, after contributions to calculus of variations by Edward J. McShane.

## Key Concepts

Optimal control deals with the problem of finding a control law for a given system such that a certain optimality criterion is achieved.(no content)A control problem includes a cost functional that is a function of state and control variables. An optimal control is a set of differential equations describing the paths of the control variables that minimize the cost function.(no content)The optimal control can be derived using Pontryagin's maximum principle (a necessary condition also known as Pontryagin's minimum principle or simply Pontryagin's principle), or by solving the Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman equation (a sufficient condition).

## Solution Methods

The search results also indicate that various computational approaches exist for solving optimal control problems, including pseudospectral methods, stochastic control approaches, and machine learning-based methods.

The search results also indicate that various computational approaches exist for solving optimal control problems, including pseudospectral methods, stochastic control approaches, and machine learning-based methods.

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about game theory:

## Definition and Overview

Game theory is the study of mathematical models of strategic interactions.(no content)It has applications in many fields of social science, and is used extensively in economics, logic, systems science and computer science.(no content)It is now an umbrella term for the science of rational decision making in humans, animals, and computers.

## Historical Development

Modern game theory began with the idea of mixed-strategy equilibria in two-person zero-sum games and its proof by John von Neumann.(no content)His paper was followed by Theory of Games and Economic Behavior (1944), co-written with Oskar Morgenstern, which considered cooperative games of several players.(no content)Initially, game theory addressed two-person zero-sum games, in which a participant's gains or losses are exactly balanced by the losses and gains of the other participant. In the 1950s, it was extended to the study of non zero-sum games, and was eventually applied to a wide range of behavioral relations.

## Major Contributors and Nobel Prizes

Fifteen game theorists have won the Nobel Prize in economics as of 2020, including most recently Paul Milgrom and Robert B. Wilson.(no content)Nash's most famous contribution to game theory is the concept of the Nash equilibrium, which is a solution concept for non-cooperative games, published in 1951. A Nash equilibrium is a set of strategies, one for each player, such that no player can improve their payoff by unilaterally changing their strategy.

## Types of Games

Cooperative games are often analyzed through the framework of cooperative game theory, which focuses on predicting which coalitions will form, the joint actions that groups take, and the resulting collective payoffs.(no content)It is different from non-cooperative game theory which focuses on predicting individual players' actions and payoffs by analyzing Nash equilibria.

Here are the search results for "Control theory":

## Overview

Control theory is a field of control engineering and applied mathematics that deals with the control of dynamical systems.(no content)The aim is to develop a model or algorithm governing the application of system inputs to drive the system to a desired state, while minimizing any delay, overshoot, or steady-state error and ensuring a level of control stability.

## How It Works

A controller monitors the controlled process variable (PV), and compares it with the reference or set point (SP). The difference between actual and desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

## History

Control theory dates from the 19th century, when the theoretical basis for the operation of governors was first described by James Clerk Maxwell.(no content)Control theory was further advanced by Edward Routh in 1874, Charles Sturm and in 1895, Adolf Hurwitz, who all contributed to the establishment of control stability criteria; and from 1922 onwards, the development of PID control theory by Nicolas Minorsky.

## Applications

Control theory is used in control system engineering to design automation that have revolutionized manufacturing, aircraft, communications and other industries, and created new fields such as robotics.(no content)Although the most direct application of mathematical control theory is its use in control systems engineering, control theory is routinely applied to problems both in the natural and behavioral sciences, including economics, operations research, and the life sciences.

Based on the search results, here's information about continuous-time systems:

## Definition

A continuous signal or a continuous-time signal is a varying quantity (a signal) whose domain, which is often time, is a continuum (e.g., a connected interval of the reals).(no content)A signal of continuous amplitude and time is known as a continuous-time signal or an analog signal. This (a signal) will have some value at every instant of time.

## Key Characteristics

In contrast, continuous time views variables as having a particular value only for an infinitesimally short amount of time. Between any two points in time there are an infinite number of other points in time.

## Comparison with Discrete-Time Systems

A discrete signal or discrete-time signal is a time series consisting of a sequence of quantities. Unlike a continuous-time signal, a discrete-time signal is not a function of a continuous argument; however, it may have been obtained by sampling from a continuous-time signal.

## Applications and Analysis

In continuous simulation, continuously changing state variables of a system are modeled by differential equations.(no content)LTI systems can also be characterized in the frequency domain by the system's transfer function, which for a continuous-time or discrete-time system is the Laplace transform or Z-transform of the system's impulse response, respectively.(no content)The electrical signals derived in proportion with the physical quantities such as temperature, pressure, sound etc. are generally continuous signals.

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about discrete-time systems:

## Overview

A discrete-time signal is a time series consisting of a sequence of quantities that is not a function of a continuous argument; however, it may have been obtained by sampling from a continuous-time signal.

## Key Characteristics

A discrete-time signal has a countable domain, like the natural numbers.(no content)In theoretical computer science, a discrete system is a system with a countable number of states.(no content)Discrete systems may be contrasted with continuous systems, which may also be called analog systems.(no content)Because discrete systems have a countable number of states, they may be described in precise mathematical models.

## Origins and Applications

When a discrete-time signal is obtained by sampling a sequence at uniformly spaced times, it has an associated sampling rate. Discrete-time signals may have several origins, but can usually be classified into one of two groups: by acquiring values of an analog signal at constant or variable rate (a process called sampling), or by observing an inherently discrete-time process.(no content)Discrete-time signal processing is for sampled signals, defined only at discrete points in time, and digital signal processing is the processing of digitized discrete-time sampled signals.

## Linear Time-Invariant Systems

A discrete-time linear time-invariant (or shift-invariant) system is defined as one operating in discrete time where the convolution in discrete time uses a discrete summation rather than an integral.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

## Analysis Complete ✅

I've successfully analyzed the paper "Adaptive Dynamic Programming for Control: A Survey and Recent Advances" and extracted all the key technologies and methodologies.

**Paper Classification:** Survey (literature review of existing ADP methods and applications)

**Extracted Triples:** 8 entities with the following breakdown:
- **Methods:** Dynamic programming, Reinforcement learning
- **Concepts:** Control theory, Game theory, Zero-sum game, Artificial intelligence, Discrete time and continuous time
- **Tasks:** Optimal control

All triples represent techniques and concepts that the paper **uses** to review and discuss ADP applications. Since this is a survey paper (not a contribution paper), it appropriately only references existing work rather than proposing new methods.

The validation passed all checks successfully, confirming that:
- Paper type is correctly classified as "survey"
- All Wikipedia URLs are valid and properly formatted
- All entity types are correctly assigned
- All relevance statements explain the connection to the paper
